hook.text: Helium was first discovered on the Sun â€” 93 million miles away â€” before it was found on Earth.

buildup.text: In 1868, astronomers saw an unknown spectral line during a solar eclipse. They named it helium.

discovery.text: Helium is produced by radioactive decay underground. Once released, it floats into space forever.

twist.text: We use helium for MRI machines, rocket fuel, and deep-sea diving. We're running out.

climax.text: Party balloons waste a non-renewable resource that took billions of years to accumulate.

punchline.text: Helium escapes Earth forever once released. Party balloons are literally wasting it.

quiz.question: Why is Earth's helium supply finite?
options: Once released, it escapes to space and can't return
Helium decays into hydrogen over time
We use it faster than radioactive decay produces it
